But the Old One. He did a Yuwipi  ceremony last night.
Crow Horse winks at Ray as he slams the kickstart. To no  avail.
The old man? He's gonna tell you who  killed Leo?
Go catch Jimmy, Ray. Really. He's  gettin' away. Go ahead, go get him.  I'm late.
Hey. Hey, those are my sunglasses  you're wearing.
Grandpa traded with me. (flips the bird) Goodbye.

And Crow Horse nails his kick start. The BIKE ROARS alive and the Indian works the throttle hard, leaving gravel an black exhaust. Ray stands there, drifting between logic a instinct. He looks at his watch, then starts at a slow,  thoughtful shuffle toward his car.

The dust-buzzard broncs and bounces down Grandpa's drivew coming to a stop near the wrecked cars. Crow Horse dismou and unhooks a carton of smokes from the back. A moment later, the junker van pulls in, bouncing and sha Crow Horse stares at the approaching vehicle, his eyes hi behind Ray's former shades. He cracks a slow smile becaus Ray is stepping quickly from the van, and carrying two pa of Marlboros.

Grandpa sits in his chair, his black eyes moving smoothly from side to side. Smoke enshrouds his ancient face, givi the sense of another time and place. He speaks LAKOTA. Crow Horse, sitting on a stool across from him, holds The Pipe. He passes it to Ray who sits in a busted lawn chair next to him. The room is dark as the sun sets out the win in red and purple. Ray looks at the pipe. Grandpa will no speak until Ray smokes. And so he does, drawing on the st awkwardly. HEARTBEAT DRUM as Grandpa speaks Indian.
He says, back behind Red Deer Table,  where the Elk-People-used-to-live...  there are strange creatures from  another world who eat stones... and  who will kill anyone who crosses  into this place.
Ray looks at Crow Horse, searching for a hint of lightnes But there is only great reverence as he watches Ray blow  smoke upward.

He says, in the Yuwipi ceremony last  night, he saw you... going back into  the land beyond Red Deer Table. I  was with you. But that was all the  Spirits let him see so he doesn't  know if you were killed or not. But  he thinks you probably were.
Ray smirks as he passes the pipe to Grandpa. Crow Horse l nervous. Grandpa offers the pipe to the directions and th disengages the bowl from the stem. He speaks again. Crow  Horse translates.
Go to the land where the Elk-People- used-to-live and you will find the  answers you came here looking for.  But you must go as two. That is the  vision. I have spoken. And this is  so.
Grandpa leans closer to Crow Horse and whispers some Lako
He wants to trade. (a beat) He likes your watch.
Ray looks at Crow Horse, nervous.
I can't do that, (explaining) It's a Rolex.
A what?
And Grandpa is already holding out something to offer. It a cigarette. Grandpa offers it again.
I'm sorry, this is -- (loud to Grandpa) -- this is very, very expensive.  It's -- (to Crow Horse) Tell him this is an expensive watch.
Crow Horse tells the Old Man. Grandpa speaks Indian.
He says, you need to go on Indian  time. He says your watch is ruining  your life anyway.
Ray buries his hands in his jacket pocket. No way. Crow H signs to Grandpa "no." Grandpa gets up, crosses between t two young men, up to the TV set. He turns it on.
explodes in PINGS AND PONGS and a WOMAN'S SHRILL SCREAM.
Crow Horse and Ray walk down the steps. WHEEL OF FORTUNE heard from within.
Red Deer Table, Ray.
Don't tell me: heavy duty.

Heavy, heavy duty. Taku Wakan. Wanagi  Spirits. It's one of those few places  we'd never go to as kids. Still don't.  Some of the old people say Crazy  Horse is buried back there. We have  to go Ray. Together. Like his vision.
They step into the yard and Ray stops, turning to Crow Ho
Walter. When I fill out my 302, do I  say that evil spirits are killing  everybody on the reservation?
Ray --
-- no. No offense to the old man. I  appreciate you trying to help. But I  put my ass on the line coming out  here, man.
What'd you expect to hear?
Not Native American myths and legends.  I'm with the FBI, Walter, remember?  Not National Geographic.
What you call myths, we call our  history.
It's not real.
What's real to you? Wall Street?  Capital Hill? Now they are myths.
I can't be dicking around here. That's  all I'm saying. I don't carry  crystals, I don't wanna come back in  another life. I just wanna do my  job, and do it right, and get the  fuck outta here.
You ain't no Indian. You're a Sal  Mineo Indian.
Crow Horse drives "Indian" home with a hard finger in Ray chest. Ray knocks his hand away, explosively. Crow Horse ready.
Knock it off!
The old man is standing at the top of the steps. Ray and  Crow Horse are YELLING OVER EACH OTHER, and hands are up.
Will ya knock it off? You're actin'  like a couple of old women.
Ray stands there, one hand up in defense, another poised throw a punch. Bewildered, he stares at the old Indian ho onto the porch railing.
For cryin' out loud. Knock it off.
He speaks English.
Only when he's really pissed off.
Come inside. Watch TV.

And Grandpa goes back in, screendoor slapping shut behind him. Ray is just staring, his jaw dropped. Crow Horse sta laughing. Harder than he has yet, and Ray starts walking  toward his car in fuck-this steps. He gets into the car, closes the door and looks out the o window at Crow Horse. The Indian moves first.
Don't accuse nothin' of not bein'  real, Little Weasel. Cuz the only  thing around here that ain't real is  you.
Ray lifts his arm off the door, and springs his middle fi up at Crow Horse. He holds it there for a long moment jus looking at the big Indian.
Take care of yourself, Walter.
Likewise.
Ray checks the time on his watch then guns away. Crow Hor stands there, watching him go. Eventually he shuffles bac toward the trailer.

Room 14 has been transformed into a major COINTELPRO base four computer terminals are set up, card tables spread wi photos, boxes of files stacked on the bed, and SIX AGENTS manning the computers, thumbing through files.
A meeting takes place around a table of paperwork and cof cups, and a .45 laid atop a file. Cooch, SA Miles, SA She TWO OTHER REGIONAL AGENTS and Ray.

We've gotten word that Jimmy has  been trying to hook up with Maggie  Eagle Bear... but some of the Warriors  have been sending word to Jimmy that  she may be an FBI operative. So he  doesn't know where to go.
Cooch taps some ashes into an empty coffee cup. They sizz in cold residue.
Bingo. It's working.
He's out of room. All the reservation  exits have been watchdogged. We got  him. I give it twelve hours.
Well we better use those twelve hours  to apprehend the right man.
The agents all look at Ray. A pin can be heard falling to the cheap carpet.
The right man? Talk to me, Ray.

Whoever dusted Leo, dusted him from  the driver's seat of a moving car  then drove those eight miles to the  Badlands. Jimmy Looks Twice has never  been behind the wheel of a car. It's  a known fact out here that he's  petrified of driving. His parents  were killed in a car wreck.
Cooch nods, lights another smoke, intrigued.
That's not very solid.
There was also a print found in the  Badlands that indicated diagetic  locomotion. Heels first. Jimmy's  walking pattern doesn't match. He  has a distinct Indian walk.
Indian walk? You been smoking hooch  in the peace pipe, Ray?
LAUGHTER. Except for Cooch who just stares at Ray, digest what he has said.
They don't smoke hooch in The Pipe,  Miles. They smoke something called  kinickinick, it's like a tobacco.
Sherman looks at Cooch.
Well, you're right about X21 being a  Washington Redskin, that's for sure.  What else, Ray?
You boys want a soda?
Oh, yeah, a Coke. You buying?
No, Ray's buying. Sherman? Coke?
Oh... no. No, Cooch, I'm working on  a coffee here. Indian walk?
Cooch nods to Ray and Ray follows, gathering up some pape He looks determined as a terrier.
Ray and Cooch throw long, slim shadows on their way to an archaic Coke machine.
Genetic ditto on evidence found at  the site with evidence you found in  his belongings. An incontrovertible  motive. And definite footprints on  Jimmy Looks Twice at Maisy Blue Legs  house.
When did we get that?
Today. And now you -- there's a dog  in the van --
-- I know. I fed it, and I can't get  rid of --

You weren't sent here to go off on  your own detail, Ray. You were sent  here to assist in a Selective  Operations Unit. These regional agents  are inept -- that's why they were  sent out here to The Graveyard, to  Indian Country. I need you behind  me, Ray. Not pulling against me.
I'm not trying to pull against you,  Cooch. I've just been having  nightmares about the way Leo was  killed.
Your first homicide, that's gonna  happen, Ray...
I just wanna make sure no one else  gets done in that way because we  were in bed with the wrong doer.
Ray. I never get into bed with  somebody unless I know for sure.  Just the way I was raised.
Ray studies him with a smile building. Cooch shrugs, sips some soda.
Alright. Alright...

(lightly) Yeah, alright, alright -- fuck you --  give a yuppie a badge and he wants  to take over the world. Go get a  tail on Eagle Bear, and stay with  her. Cuz Jimmy's gonna show. And I  want you to make the collar.
Ray nods, starting for the van.
Ray.
He turns. Cooch looks at him for a time. It is a warm loo
I'll sleep around a little.
Thanks, Cooch.
And get rid of the dog.
Ray gets in and pulls the dog out. The dog sits at roadsi tilting its head at him, confused. And he pulls out. It r after him.

The van sits parked down the road from Maggie's dimly-lit home. Ray sits behind the wheel, watching the house. LOCU make a steady and unnerving sound. It is black. Black und big sky. Ray lets his head sag out the open window and he takes in the vastness. POV: stars. Millions of stars. And an incredible full moo It hangs huge over distant fields, a perfect sphere. The half of the moon is yellow, the bottom half a lava red.

stares at it, lost in thought. From Maggie's house, he he someone SINGING. Singing a traditional SUNDANCE SONG whil they haul water from the creek. A WOMAN'S VOICE, trilling out the beautiful but haunting "hey-o-hey-o-hey-o-hey-ohh Ray just sits, listening. And then something draws his  attention to his rearview mirror. The res dog, lying in the back seat is GROWLING. Lip curl back, growling low. Ray looks at him, looks out the window. Blackness. Nothin but the sound of locusts. And a slight crosswind in the w fields. The dog stops growling. And Ray fixes his gaze on the house again, lifting a pair of binoculars and -- BOOOOOOM! The rear windshield is SHATTERED by an explosio Ray throws himself low across the passenger seat -- BOOOO The driver's side window and part of the door explodes.
The federal van is HAMMERED BY GUNFIRE. All the windows,  shattered, the metal doors splayed. Someone is going for kill,

is thrown open just as its window implodes, and Ray slide out belly first, gripping his M-16 and crawling like a do soldier into tall wheat at roadside as the car, the road, the wheat, the dirt, the night are slammed by gunfire. The res dog overtakes Ray and vanishes in the wheat. Ray  vanishes, too. It is quiet for a moment, then Ray, pops u ten feet away, and UNLOADS THE M-16, in a left to right,  clean sweep before dropping again. He lies there, listeni The LOCUST HAVE GONE QUIET. His breath is heavy. His hear got to be pounding through the dirt he lays in.
(whispering) Motherfucker.
the decimated van, aerial still high. The distant lights Maggie's house. And the giant Moon, hovering over it all. HEARTBEAT DRUM into --
TWENTY FEDS comb the dirt road, the wheat fields, picking shells with gloved hands, scanning the vast distance. IN THE FRONT YARD of Maggie's, FOUR INDIAN CHILDREN stand with the Old Woman, watching.

location: LE BARON TRAVELING ANOTHER DIRT ROAD

text: Cooch, flushed in the face, mans the wheel. He wears only T-shirt which indicates, a desperate rush to the scene. H eyes scan the surrounding homes and fields. In the passenger seat, Ray sits, drinking a coffee. He lo haggard.
Bastards...
All I could think of was... not here.  I don't wanna eat it on an Indian  Reservation, three thousand miles  from home.
He's out there. He's out there playing  Sitting Bull with us. I want the  motherfucker so bad I'm getting a  bleeding ulcer.
Ray turns around in his seat, looking off across dry land
It may have been Maggie's way of  saying "get off my ass."
She's that subtle?
Eagle's claws and a bear's balls  that's what her profile says.
Well, she's running now, too. These  fucking people like to run, don't --
-- Cooch. Woh. Stop.
He does. Ray is turned around in his seat, staring off in the distance.

The Le Baron whines backward, and off the road, into some grass Ray steps out, keeping his gaze fixed. Cooch bails  from the driver's side, joins him. HEARTBEAT DRUM. RAY'S POV: Four-hundred feet across a flat area of sandst and grass clusters, something shimmers in the undulations the harsh morning sun. Something of pea green and rusty  metal... glass catches sunlight and makes prisms. A car. old res car, sitting in a long, chasm in barely a foot of green water.
Ray and Cooch go through the car, around the car, with gl hands and grease pencils and plastic bags, sweating in th hot sun.
Tread matches. It's the car.
Yes.
Excited, Ray walks off, scanning the area.
But this doesn't make any sense,  Ray. If it's just been sitting in  this dry wash for seven days... why  the hell didn't we find it?
Ray picks up a handful of stones, sifts them in his hands
Because this isn't a dry wash.
Cooch watches him slosh shoes first through a rut where t water shimmers a foot deep or less.
It's the Little Walking River.
Ray turns, shucking up mud.
And it was full of water when I drove  by here three days ago. Full. I  mean... a river.
The Little Walking River. You're  right. This is part of it. So whoever  sunk this car didn't compensate for  drought. Goddamn.
Ray doesn't hear Cooch. He stares past the SAC at the lon wide chasm, wet in some places, arid in others, and what hears must be an echo in his head.
Listen to the water...

Cooch is listening to a TRANSMISSION across his radio and walks off a few feet, exchanging information with the  REGIONALS. Ray stands, ankle deep in stagnant water, his face sweat- soaked, his eyes transfixed on heat undulations.

A flat-bed tow truck drives past the motel with the kille car on it. Behind the truck is a fed car which stops at t motel, and the Le Baron which also pulls in. Miles and Sh get out from the first car, Ray and Cooch bail from the L Baron. With RADIOS TRANSMITTING, the agents walk, dusty and tire into room 14. Ray hesitates, snagged by the sight of -- A motorcycle parked in front of the Buffalo Butte Bar. Pa with pick-up trucks and station wagons. It's the mud-cake old Barley. Parked right under the NO INDIANS sign. He puzzles over this.

Dark. Even during the day. Cigarette smoke. Sawdust. On t archaic juke box, RANDY TRAVIS sings "Old 8x10" while beh the bar, the BAR OWNER, an old man with long white hair a beard, busies himself with leather work. SEVERAL WHITE LO sit on the old water drum bar stools. Heads lift, turn when Ray enters in his "fraternizing" cl jeans and boots, leather jacket. He scuffs up thick sawdu as he heads to the furthest booth back where -- Crow Horse sits, alone over a bourbon and a beer. Ray  approaches carefully, upset by the sight. He slides into booth and point blanks the Indian.
Agent Little Weasel, Federal Bura of  your Imagination.
Jesus Christ. You're hammered. What  are you doing?

You're right about the old man. His  power's long dried up. He's supposed  to be a medicine man but he won't go  see the people. He says we changed,  and we don't listen. Well, he don't  go out and talk no more. I haven't  had a drink in three years but I  just turned my sobriety chip into  that man behind the bar, and this  Hoss is gettin' watered.
Cut the shit. You shouldn't be in  here, Man.
Cuz I'm a skin?
Cuz you're a cop.
Not no more.
What are you talking about?
You tell me. You tell me who went to  the B.I.A. -- Bureau of Indian  Annihilation and said I was messin'  with your case, man. I don't give a  goddamn about your case.
And I don't give a goddamn about  whether you wear a badge or not,  Crow Horse, but I didn't cut you.
Crow Horse shimmers his black eyes onto Ray.
Still after Jimmy?
They found prints at Blue Legs' place.

Yeah. Jimmy's prints are there. But  they cross over Benjamin Black Star's  prints. And he wasn't there until  six o'clock the mornin' after to get  eggs from the chickens. So Jimmy  wasn't there til the next day. Follow?
Ray just looks vacantly at Crow Horse. Crow Horse resents the vacancy.
Look, man... you better bust Jimmy  and get out before somebody shoots  up more than your car next time.
Ray glares at him.
Next time I'll be ready. You get the  word to who ever it is.
I can't, Hoss. I don't talk to FBI's.
Ray doesn't blink.
You think you was sent here cuz you're  a good cop?
No. I was sent here cuz I'm Indian.  And a good cop.
Crow Horse leans toward Ray and speaks more quietly.

You ever think that maybe you was  sent here cuz the FBI's need one  good reason to take out the entire  Warrior Movement. And what better  reason than one of their men, gettin'  blown away on the res. A low-rent,  expendable public servant sent in to  take a bullet for his country.
Ray is fuming. He can't believe what he's hearing, what's being insinuated, but he's giving it thought and it's get him angry. He smashes a hand down on the table.
I'm sick of your shit --
I'm sick of the two of ya timber  niggers spewin' off.

Standing over the booth is a long, tall RANCHER'S SON. Ra with red curly hair tucked under a BLACK HILLS CLASSIC ca and arms built by tractor work. And behind him, TWO OLDER RANCHERS fall in. And ANOTHER YOUNG MAN, grinning with  amusement. Ray and Crow Horse look up.
Sorry, we don't speak United States.
Yeah, well I do. Get the Jesus up,  and get the Jesus out or I'm gonna  go out to my truck and come back  with my hardware.
Woh, hold on there, Jack, you're --
-- don't "jack" me, Squanto. I'll  bury your lazy ass right here.
Ray realizes now that they think he's Indian, too. Crow H sees this revelation and complicates it by suddenly speak LAKOTA to Ray. The rancher grabs Ray by the cheeks.
I'm talkin' to --

Ray decks him. Backhands him in the solar plexus then, la a burner of a Quantico roundhouse to his ear, knocking hi across the bar, over a mop and bucket and into sawdust. The others start to fall at him but someone has jumped in holding them back, and sticking himself in the way. It is Brooks. The old timer Ray met his first night here.
No! No, you butt holes! He ain't  skin! He AIN'T SKIN!
Yeah he's In'dn. Miniconjou Sioux.

The rancher's son who is coming back with a broken beer  bottle, slows his step and shifts his eyes from Brooks to the young fed There is a lot of heavy breathing. But no  talking just yet. The young rancher eyes Ray.
You ain't Indian?

Ray just stands tense, staring at him. And it's strange.  Because he hasn't really looked like he has any Indian bl up to this moment. But dressed the way he is, and his eye glaring, face drawing tense, he might pass for a breed  although that's probably the Italian. But Ray doesn't ans the question. Crow Horse starts laughing. Drunkenly.
What's so damn funny?
Well, it's just that the cavalry  used to always threaten the Lakota.  The cavalry ain't around anymore.  The Lakota still are.
I got no trouble tellin' where you  come from, Fat Red.

Crow Horse rises and walks unsteadily across the floor,  leaving the bar. Brooks is whispering to the others,  apparently about who Ray is. The bar man comes up to Ray, holding a tray, on which sits a shot and a beer. Ray look at it for a moment.
Sorry. On the house.
Ray knocks the tray out of his hand, spilling beer and wh all over the bar man and the locals around him. And he walks out, leaving the locals confused.
Ray looks strung-out as he drives. If it's not the confli at the Butte, it's the dangerous seed Crow Horse planted, and it is playing with his mind. He is on his RADIO.
No plates. No registration. Serial  numbers removed. And all prints washed  off by the river. That's great. This  is turning out to be a walk in the  park, do you know that?
(woman agent) Come back?
Never mind.
But before he hangs the radio. IT CUTS BACK IN.
Ray. X22.
I read, Cooch.
Remember that upside down flag back  at Jimmy's house? Somebody took it  down.
Good.
They took it down, set fire to it,  and threw it on the doorstep of room  13 at the Buffalo Butte Motel. Your  room.
Ray seethes quietly as he drives.

We traced the number of the truck  that dumped it, and it belongs to  one Maggie Sanders, also known as  Maggie Eagle Bear. She's been all  over the res, riling up the  traditionals, telling them not to  break, and to keep Jimmy in hiding.  She's a problem now. And she's yours.  Get her off the reservation.
Ray keeps driving.

Maggie's old pick-up is parked near an arch gate of the t cemetery where a tall monument is fenced off from other g There are tobacco offerings and other medicines hanging o the fence and on the monument. It is a quiet place. Still. Maggie stands before the unkempt monument in her denim ja her hair blowing across her face in the wind. She PRAYS I LAKOTA. Behind her TEN CHILDREN from the Bear Creek School stand, heads bowed respectfully. Two of them sit on the lap of  Richard Yellow Bird who looks on from his wheelchair, pra quietly with Maggie. When Maggie completes her prayer, sh ties some tobacco to the monument then turns and faces th children. One of them, a LITTLE GIRL -- heavy-set -- rais a hand that we might note is deformed. As many of the chi we have seen on the res, are.
Are they all right under here?
Two-hundred and sixty-seven men,  women, old people. And little ones  like you. Many killed running along  that road you see there.
Where were they runnin' to?

A place called The Stronghold. (a beat) They died for a dream. But you live.  You are their great-great  grandchildren and you live. We have  to honor their dream. Of protecting  the Mother Earth. And being proud of  being Indian.
My mother told me that they call us  Indians cuz Columbus was lookin' for  India when he discovered our country.
Maggie smiles at the boy.
Yeah, well, let me tell you something,  Henry: just be glad he wasn't looking  for Turkey.

The CHILDREN LAUGH. All but one boy, who isn't paying  attention. He is staring up at a hill, off in the distanc MAGGIE'S POV: on the hill, a figure stands, hands in his  pockets, hair blowing in the wind. Ray.
keeping her eyes on the Wasi'cu, but addressing Yellow Bi
Richard. Sing the Honoring Song with  them. I'll be right back.
Ray stands, watching Maggie walking into the wind, toward him. Behind her an HONORING SONG, sung by ten children ha the still air. He doesn't budge as she mounts the gentle bluff and joins him there.
We're praying at the grave. Do you  wanna join us?
A long silence. The voices carry in the wind.
No, Maggie. But you're gonna have to  join me for a ride. I'm taking you  to Rapid City.
Maggie looks at him. They lock eyes.
So much power. I see it in your eyes.  This... hunger for power. Or for  what you think is power.
As if exhausted by the thought, Maggie sits down on the b looking out at the children who are still singing the son As she speaks, she begins digging her fingers in the eart Ray stands over her.
You burned an American flag today.  And left it for me...
-- You desecrated it, it had to be  burned.
I desecrated it?

You forced an innocent man to run  like an animal. You've tried to poison  my people's hearts against me with  your manipulation, with letters I  never wrote... you've been watching  me eat, work, raise my family...  wash myself in the river. And now  you're here, arresting me at a sacred  place. (a beat) In your eyes, that's power.
Maggie lifts herself onto her knees and looks down into t small hole she's dug. She picks up a little pine cone.

So I plant this tree for you. And I  take all this stuff that you've laid  on me and my people, and I put it in  this hole with this pine cone. (she covers it) And I bury it. Cuz ya know what it  is, Ray? Bullshit. And shit is  fertilizer. (she stands) And The Mother will turn your lies  into something that lives.
Maggie rises, dusting off her hands. She looks him in the soul.
That's what power is, in the Indian  way. (holds her hands out  to be cuffed) Take me to Rapid, Ray. I'm the enemy.
Ray just stares at her, struggling with what he's feeling what he's hearing. What he's supposed to be feeling. Sile hangs between the two of them.
If I told you... that I think Jimmy's  innocent... but I'm in over my head...  would you believe me?
Maggie looks at him, considering. Then toward the long da silhouette of a mountain range across the plains.

See those Black Hills out there,  Ray? When the people lost the land  in 1868, the government took  everything but those hills. They  allowed us to keep those Black Hills,  to live there. Signed a treaty. Until  they found gold. Then they told us  we had to leave because of National  interest. They broke that treaty.  Anyone who fought or spoke out against  it, wound up dead or in jail. And  the people wound up here. On a  reservation.
While she looks off at Paha Sapa, Ray stares at her profi
While up there, in the Black Hills...  they carved the faces of four  presidents.
She looks at Ray with an ironic smile, and she catches hi transfixed.
Your relatives must've taught you  something.
NO. (after thought) My father never told anybody he had  Indian blood. But he still used a  few Indian words around the house.  He called me Washee. Said it meant...  good boy.
Maggie starts giggling.
What?
Wa-shee is like... a dumpling. Like  tallow we put in stew. I think he  was calling you chubby boy.
Great.

Maggie is laughing as she looks back at the children who no longer singing. Ray reaches inside his jacket and take out five polaroids. He shuffles them as he ponders. He ha one to Maggie who has caught herself opening up too much the Wasi'cu.
You ever see that car before?
Maggie looks at the first photo and says nothing. She han it back quickly. Ray won't take it.
Who's it belong to?
Maggie ignores him. Ray studies her reaction.
Help me, Maggie...

Maggie is looking away. She picks a long blade of grass a smoothes it in her hands. Ray looks at her a moment longer then rises, dusting off jeans, and standing there. He thinks for a long moment,  pinches the bridge of his nose, then looks out at the Bla Hills, pensive.
I didn't see you today, Maggie. (a beat) Goodbye.
Maggie watches him go. Looks away. Then watches him again
Goodbye... Wa-shee.

Ray stops. She stands on the bluff, her hair riding the w and her eyes searing. And then her lips do something that might qualify as half a smile. A sense of humor rising up through anger. Survival humor. Ray looks at her for a long moment. And then he walks on, leaving her there.
Ray sits behind the wheel, going through files on his lap photographs of Indians. And thinking hard.
Anyone who fought or spoke out against  it... wound up dead or in jail.
Ray looks out the window toward the monument.
(to himself, flustered) That was 1868, Maggie...

Exhausted, Ray lays his head back on the seat, and lets a long, constricted breath free. THUNDER ROLLS like the slo deep roar of some giant bear up in the hills. He opens hi eyes, looks out the window. POV: rain is coming down, and Maggie is getting the child into the back of her truck. She helps them get a tarp ove their heads. Then as Yellow Bird pulls himself into the c of the truck, she hefts the wheelchair and two boys load in. She gets in, starts up, and rolls off down the sloping ro

Ray steps out of the car into the rain and closes the doo He stares at the burial grounds. Then slowly, he starts t them as if magnetically drawn. HEARTBEAT DRUM. A shroud of mist lays over the cemetery, growing thicker the rain falls harder. DRUM BEATS DEEPER. Ray is walking  toward the memorial, getting drenched. Then he hears some strange. HOOFBEATS.

coming down the dirt road, toward him, a HORSEMAN drives mount at a fast trot. The rider is only a vague image in mist, his face hidden. As he rides closer, we can make ou shotgun in his hand. And he throws it up, takes aim.

paralyzed for a moment. And then going for his gun. But i not there. He's left it in the car. He breaks into a run. But there's a shorter distance now between the horseman a the car and Ray has no choice but to turn and flee. His boots slap wet pavement, and his breath draws heavy a desperate as he bounds off the road and races down a gras slope, looking over his shoulder, panicking. His legs and arms churning, his face contorted. And then  someone passes him out, running just as hard. AN INDIAN W in 1890 Winter rags, clutching a BABY to her breast and  CRYING. SCREAMING. Ray looks at her, incredulous as he ru But he keeps running. The rider is right behind him. He FIRES. The GUNSHOT CRAC the sky like thunder. BOOOOM!

Ray jumps awake. Cooch is POUNDING on the window. And the three-legged dog inside is BARKING. Ray quickly rolls the window down, letting in THUNDER. Cooch starts to say something then takes note of Ray's pe face. Sweat runs down his temples, beads at his nose.
Jesus, you alright?
Yeah. I... I fell asleep. I can't  believe it. I --
Never turn your radio off! I thought  I was gonna find you scalped! Damn  it!
Sorry, Cooch. I lost Eagle Bear --
-- never mind Eagle Bear. We've got  Jimmy nailed. Let's go!
And Cooch runs to his car. Ray fires the car's big engine and takes off behind Cooch who is driving a fed Chevy. CR

The rain pelts Grandpa's little Airstream trailer, wind s at sheet plastic in the windows. An ancient sewing wheel  CREAKS RUSTY in the wind. Three clean, late-model fed cars pull down the muddy driv as two SWAT vehicles pull in from another road. The Le Ba pulls in, and Ray bails out with the others. When he sees where he is, he looks distraught. Agents are running behind junked cars, positioning themse around the trailer.

head_text.subj: INT. GRANDPA REACHES TRAILER LATE DAY

text: The holy man is sitting in his chair, smacking Flies with swatter. Tonight he wears a black reservation hat and sta vacantly at the TV where RONALD MACDONALD swings a giant  baseball bat, and falls on his face, bouncing back up. An then BOOM! The door is open and Cooch leads Miles, Sherman and Ray  inside. Cooch has a gun on the old man.
HANDS ON YOUR HEAD!

The old man slowly removes his hat and hangs it on a knee Carefully he places his wrinkled hands on his thinning wh hair. His eyes seek out Ray who stands in the doorway, M- in hand, looking concerned. He stares at Ray. Cooch storms into a back bedroom, Miles moves to a window Sherman stands over the old man.
Where is he, Sam? Where's Jimmy?
Grandpa looks at Sherman, ignores him, looks back at Ray.
He's a medicine man, Ray. The  "spiritual leader" of the Warriors.  That right, Sam?
With RADIO TRANSMISSIONS crackling through the house, Coo comes back down the hall, and heads to the door.
Trailer's clean, let's go.
Ray starts to follow but he sees Sherman pick something u from near Grandpa. The 500 year-old turtleshell rattle.  Grandpa's eyes widen slightly.
You been the one making it rain like  that, out there, Sam?
Hey, put that down.
Can you make Jimmy outrun an M-16,  Sam?
Sherman!

Sherman drops the turtleshell rattle on the linoleum floo Then drives his heel into it, CRUSHING the fragile  turtleshell. Ray grabs him and slams him into the tin wall. Miles gets between them, grabbing Sherman.
EASY, MEN! HEY! --
HE'S ON THE ROOF! HE'S ON THE FUCKING  ROOF! COME ON GUYS, COME ON, GUYS!
They're out the door, leaving the old man to sit looking  down at the shattered rattle. He closes his eyes.

In a blizzard of rain, Jimmy Looks Twice in a cowboy shir jeans and boots, leaps off the top of the Airstream, clut his medicine bundle. FLOODLIGHTS HIT him from all directi BULLHORNS screaming at him. He tries to turn a corner and runs right into a fed. Ray, having run out the back door has slammed right into him. has his rifle on him, and they stare each other down for split second before he is converged on. Guns at his back, his head. He is swept off his feet, face down, and frisked. He look up at Ray, desperately.
Brother, the old man told me about  you. Listen to me: what was Leo trying  to tell me? He wanted to meet me at  Maisy --
Another fed, pushes his face into the mud, cuffs him behi his back.
Save your speeches for prison, Jimmy.
With two FIVE MAN SWAT TEAMS swarming the area, and six a pushing Jimmy toward a car, Cooch stands there in the pou rain, looking relieved. Ray stands near him, looking abho
Damn. That's one hard running Indian.
Ray watches Jimmy as he is shoved into the back of Miles Sherman's car and driven away. He is twisting around in h seat to look at Ray. Desperately. The SWAT teams disband, return to their vehicles.
It's over, Ray. I aged five years.  But it's over. At least I'm gonna  look like I'm ready for the advisory  desk. Let's go get a beer.

Cooch heads to his car and Ray starts shuffling toward hi as if he is dared by it all. He is looking at the trailer and there on the rickety porch is Grandpa. He comes down steps slowly, holding his hat on against the wind. He wat the cars pulling out. Ray walks over to him, looking sick.
Look... I'm not who you think I am. (a long beat) I'm sorry.
And after a moment of locking gazes, he starts for his ca
Out back that way... is a placed  called Wounded Knee.
Ray turns.

I was one years old there when our  people were shot down. My mother hid  me in the snow in a blanket. One of  those killed was a Holy Man called  Wakiyan Cante -- Thunder Heart. They  killed him while he was running for  The Stronghold. It is his blood --  the same blood that spilled on the  grass and snow at Wounded Knee --  that runs through your heart like a  buffalo.
Ray frowns, disturbed by this story. The old man is speaking with conviction. With power.

Thunder Heart has come. Sent here to  a troubled place to help his people.  That's what I am told. Maybe you're  right and I am mistaken. Your mind  is young, mine is old. If so, so be  it. Ho Hecetu Yelo. I'll speak no  more.

Ray stands, almost paralyzed, digesting this. He turns an looks into the old man's sharp eyes. Grandpa has closed h eyes, and as he is pulverized by the rain, he turns his f toward it and from way down in his belly, he begins to SI IN LAKOTA. And it is too much. Too weird. He wheels and  hurries to the car. Gets in, and beats a fast path out of the old man's lonesome patch of land. BLUE HEAT LIGHTNING knifes the sky. THUNDER ROLLS, and ru into POOL BALLS --

The agents have taken over both sides of the streets, gat in front of the bar and the motel, putting firearms into  cases, removing flak jackets. POOL BALLS knock from inside the bar while outside, A DAK takes a piss near a truck while his GIRLFRIEND stands at back, yelling at him. CHARLIE DANIELS sings country on th juke Ray heads to room 13, starts unlocking the door. Coo comes up behind him.
Buffalo burgers and cold beer,  Raymond. Don't worry about the sign  out front... you don't have to be  Indian anymore.
Cooch throws a mock punch at Ray and he mock blocks, tire He musters a smile. But he isn't all there.
You have a fever. You okay?
Ray nods. Cooch lets a few agents walk past, LAUGHING. He speaks quietly.

Listen: when we get back tomorrow,  you're gonna find Tully laying a  promotion on you. S.A.C. He wants to  prove that his yuppie agents are  making good. He's offering you New  York. Tell him you want Atlanta.
Why?
Cuz I want New York.
Ray tries to break a smile again. Cooch cups his arm.

Cooch. They sent us out here because  the place was being neglected. Now,  all of a sudden, there's two five  man SWAT teams out there tonight.  Bell Huey choppers flying all over  the place. Federal occupation to  catch one guy. Why, Cooch? What's  going on?
Cooch stares at Ray. The younger agent looks like he inde has a fever.
National security, Ray. Get some  sleep. Tomorrow, we fly.
Cooch hurries across the rain-swept street. Ray steps ins and closes the door.

Ray closes the door, and stands there. He seems to be hav trouble breathing. He looks down at his boots. There is  something on the floor. Something that has been slipped u the door earlier. He just stares down at it. Then slowly  stoops. CLOSE ON: the polaroid of the res car he gave to Maggie  earlier. She has returned it. He turns it over. Written across the whi backing of the photo, in dark black marker is the name -- YELLOW BIRD. Ray stares at this for a moment then hurries over to boxe of files on the bed. He rummages like a nervous thief and comes up with a folder. He flips through it, casting off  files and 302's and profiles and finally stopping on -- The 8x10 BLACK AND WHITE of Richard Yellow Bird seen earl Sitting in his wheelchair, Red Power cap on, tattoos marr big arms. And under it a DOUBLE MUG SHOT stamped LEAVENWO PRISON. Under that ANOTHER PRISON MUG SHOT stamped SIOUX  FALLS PRISON. And under that a -- THIRD MUG SHOT stamped "PAROLED." Ray, his eyes fixed on this one, takes a few steps and si on the end of the bed. He then stuffs the file back in a  box, and takes off toward the door.
The Le Baron throws up loose rock and red dust, driving t a place where the sun begins a slow drop behind the Black Hills. HORSES run out of the road. HEARTBEAT DRUM.

A tarpaper shack. Outhouse. Clothesline on which jerked m hangs. No cars. A lonely, unnerving place. Le Baron pulls in. Ray gets out, adjusting the gun at the back of his  waistband. He starts for the shack. Ray raps a fist on th splintered plywood door. Knocks again. He checks out a bo up window. The door finally opens. Just a crack. Tiny bla eyes peer out into the fading light.
I'm looking for Richard Yellow Bird.
Ray sticks his open badge, gold eagle wings, near the cra The door closes. Then unlatches and opens. Yellow Bird si there in his wheelchair, tiny tobacco bundles in his lap. He's been tying them.
The Washington Redskin. Thought you'd  be gone by now.
He pivots his chair to allow Ray room to enter.

Yellow Bird, in a T-shirt that reveals twenty different i tattoos, rolls himself across the warped floorboards to a cheese crate where his eye glasses sit. He puts the thick bifocals on and focuses resentfully on Ray in the ochre  flicker of the dirty room.
What ya want?
Must be a bitch getting around in  that wheelchair. How long you been  in it?
Since I got a iron pipe put across  my knees, man. Fight with three  wasi'cus, ya know.
At Sioux Falls Pen?
No, that was Leavenworth. This -- (shows a scar) was Sioux Falls. What ya want?
Leavenworth a tough joint?
Ray walks across the room, his eyes on a covert mission.
You ever try solitary confinement?
No. Can't say that I have, Richard.  Richard do you know why I'm here?
Washington sent ya. I know that.
Yes, Washington sent me, Richard.  They sent me here because this whole  thing has been fucked. Do you know  what I mean when I say this whole  thing has been fucked, Richard?
Yellow Bird stares at Ray.
An arrangement was made between you...  and us. Do you remember that  arrangement?
Yellow Bird looks at Ray, strangely, shaking his head. Ra starts to look like maybe the game's not working. Like ma this doesn't add up. But --
I'm here, ain't I?
Ray lets a tense breath out.
Not for long, Richard. You got early  parole under the stipulation that  you would help us in a situation,  and you didn't deliver.
What the fuck you talkin' about?

Ray sits in a busted chair, reaches down to his ankle hol and pulls out a .38. He holds it, resting it on the arm o the chair. He strains to look out through the boarded win Yellow Bird fidgets in his chair.
Get up out of the chair, Richard.
What's with you people? Why do ya  have to fuck with my head all the  time? I came through, man.
Get up out of the chair, and walk  toward the backdoor, Richard.
(not moving) I get thrown in solitary until I  don't know my own fuckin' name, and  then you people tell me I can beat  nine years if I help you. I helped  you!
Get up!
Yellow Bird stands. He takes a step forward. Limping. He' got leg problems but he can walk. Heels first. And bowed. But he can walk. He is shaking.

They said I'd never see FBI again,  and I'm livin' with you fuckers. I  don't feed ya information on the  Warriors, it's back to the pen. I  don't do this, back to the pen. Your  word against my word. Against a con  Indian's word. I really got a chance,  man, right?
They sent me here, Richard because  they said you didn't hold up your  end of the arrangement, and I have  to transport you back to Leavenworth.
(crying) What the fuck, man? What do you people  want? I did what you wasi'cu's told  me to do.
Leo Fast Elk... is alive.
Yellow Bird wheels.
No way. No fuckin' way.
How the hell do you know?
I blew his back out with a buffalo  gun, that's how I know! Now you're  gonna say I didn't, so you can throw  me back in solitary?

Ray is trying hard not to reveal his horror at this  confession, at this understanding of the machinery. He si there with his gun, blinking away sweat that beads at his brow. Yellow Bird is weeping in a highpitched voice that  doesn't match his great bulk.
The men who came to see you at  Leavenworth. The one's who made the  arrangement... who were they? Maybe  I can talk to them.
Miles. Three other suits. That's all  I know 'em as -- suits. Were you  there?
You turned Leo over on his face. But  the coyotes must've turned him back  over, man, cuz his spirit is out.  It's out, and it knows.
What do you know about spirits? You  ain't no In'dn.
Leo knew something heavy and was  trying to tell Jimmy. But you must  not know how serious it was or you  would have delivered. Do you realize  what Leo could have told Jimmy?! Do  you?!
I took him out before he got the  chance. He didn't say nothin' about  Tashka Sha. And now his spirit is in  the dirt. Forever.
What's Tashka Sha, speak English,  speak English!
Red Deer Table! What's with you,  man?
Ray grabs onto these words, rolls them silently on his li And now Yellow Bird is getting suspicious of the fed.
Wait a minute. Wait -- what are you  doin'? You ain't a FBI. You ain't  the law. Let me see your --
Ray snaps out his gun, straight-armed.
I'm the fucking law!
Yellow Bird jumps back, raising his hands.
Keep talking, Yellow Bird...
All I know... is I did what I did...  and I ain't in solitary, gettin'  pumped up with downer, gettin' beat  to shit. But I tell you what, Suit.  Take me back. Cuz I can't take this  shit no more.

And then HEADLIGHTS pierce the gaps in the boarded window Yellow Bird collapses against the wall, bangs his head of it. He lets a long, pained, cry escape from under his bre and he begins a slow slide down the wall, to the floor. Ray peers out the cracks in the boards.
Man, I don't know who the fuck I am  no more.
Ray gets up, putting his gun away and heading to the door He stops and looks back at the Indian, sitting on the flo clutching his knees, staring into the kerosene flicker.
You and me both.
Yellow Bird looks at him, his glasses foggy, his face  contorted And Ray leaves.

Ray steps out into the falling night. There is a car park there. With a high aerial. Ray raises a hand in a slight  wave, walks on. At the fed car, A REGIONAL AGENT behind t wheel, waves a hand. Watches Ray get into the Le Baron. Ray gets in the car and takes off.

Ray drives like a crazy man through the dark reservation. Through miles of open land and strange rock formations. A he looks trapped. HEADLIGHTS flicker in his rearview. He  sees this. Slams the gas pedal.
The Le Baron races at 85 down the dirt stretch. A moment  later a car rattles by at 90.

Ray reaches over to the passenger seat and pulls up the M 16. He lays it across his lap. Looks in the rearview agai Then makes a sudden sharp turn. He pulls off the road quickly, throwing up dust into the  already foggy night, the car goes out of control.
The car that was following drives right past the narrow l hidden by grassy slopes and keeps flying down the long  stretch.

Ray skids through the dirt, trying to stop -- he can't -- and the Le Baron fishtails, smashing into a chain-link fe And coming to a stop. Breathing as if he's been running not driving, Ray looks  behind him to make sure he lost the car. He did. When he  turns back to his wheel, he sees --
lit by his headlights: THE WOUNDED KNEE gravesite. He is  right up on the arch, and the tall stone marker beyond it

The Le Baron just sits parked, headlights making the nigh fog crawl up from the base of the old tomb, along the fen The driver's door opens slowly. And Ray steps out. He wal through the arch. Into the small fenced area. Up to the s which is overgrown with stubborn weeds, half-hidden in mi Ray studies the tomb.
Weeds are grown up over the rest of the names. Ray's hand clear them, grab at them and rip them away from more name
With frantic abandon, Ray is ripping weeds away. He drops his knees, clearing weeds.
MOVING DOWN and then suddenly back up to the name:

kneeling in the weeds, the wind getting restless around h screaming the way plains winds do but only these winds ar filled with a whistling. What sounds like EAGLE BONE WHIS piping shrill. Ray kneels before the marker, staring at the name on the  stone, his hair thrown around by the wind that drives acr the grass, whistling eagles, building to an unbearable, p Ray stares at the name as if he is looking through a smal hole into another world. A world that frightens him. He g up and backs away from the stone, through the gate. And g back in his car, quickly. He takes off.
The little home on the river. Dark. Empty. Ray runs up th steps, pounds at the door. No answer. Pounds again.
Maggie!

He keeps knocking. Nothing. He hurries back down the step starts around the back of the house and something attacks him, leaps at him from the dark, knocking him off his fee into the grass. Hits him again. But as quickly as he falls, he rolls, throwing up his han and blocking a savage kick aimed for his face. He traps t boot, twists it and drops the attacker onto his back. In matter of seconds, he is on top of the man, sticking his in his throat. He grabs a flashlight from his jacket and  shines it in the man's face. Crow Horse. Breathing like a wild animal.
Five-hundred year old turtleshell  rattle...
Crow Horse, listen --
Where's Maggie? Where'd ya take her.
Nowhere. I'm trying to find her.
You got Jimmy. Let her go.
Crow Horse, listen. You have to come  with me.
Why? So you can get rid of me, too?
No. So we can do what the old man  said. Red Deer Table, Walter. We  have to go.
Crow Horse lies there, breathing heavy. Ray on top of him still clutching his gun.
Ray and Crow Horse are quiet as they eat up the dirt road
Maybe the old man's visions are still  strong.
Ray nods, concentrating. After a time:
Do they come in dreams, these visions?
Oh yeah. Dreams. Sometimes durin'  sickness. Vision quest. Sweat Lodge.  Ya never know when.
Just before we caught Jimmy... I had  a dream that I was being chased. And  I was running with other people. Old- fashion Indian people. I got shot in  the back. Like Leo.
When Crow Horse doesn't respond, Ray looks over and finds him staring. He looks back to the road. And when he looks back at Crow Horse, he is still staring at him.
Where was this?
At Wounded Knee. I mean, that's where  I was, and that's where the dream  was. Why?
You were running with the old ones.  At The Knee. Heavy duty.
Well, it was just a dream, I --
Sonuvabuck! What's with you, Man?  Who are you?
What do you mean?
Nothin'. Forget it.
Crow Horse looks out the window as if to avoid Ray who is confused by the Indian's smoldering. After a moment, Crow Horse looks at him.

You had a vision. You had yourself a  vision. A man waits a long time for  a vision. Might go his whole lifetime  and never get one. And along comes  some instant Indian with a Mastercard  and brand-new shoes, has himself a  vision.
Sorry.
I'm a full-blood Oglala.
We've driven a long way. Where is  this place?
Maybe it was just a dream. Ya know,  just one of them, what do ya call  'em, fitful dreams?
Yeah. Fitful dreams.
Crow Horse feels better. He looks out the window, nodding But it doesn't last long.
Bullshit. You had a vision. You got  sign from the old ones.
What the hell do you want me to do?!
Stop.

Ray brakes. Crow Horse is looking past him. Ray turns. Th spectacular mesa that we have admired with every sunrise, looms massive now that we are under it. Moonlight falls o it. And the HEARTBEAT DRUM pulses from it.

The land behind Red Deer Table is Badlands. Badlands pier by a few rutted old wagon roads. At a place between two  grotesque buttes, Crow Horse stops, looking uneasy. He digs into his pocket, pulls out some loose tobacco and spills it on the ground. Then he walks on. Ray observes this, starting forward, then stopping long e to fish a cigarette out from his pocket and drop it next Crow Horse's offering.

Ray and Crow Horse walk, carefully under a full moon, sca the area. Crow Horse stops, checks out some tracks. Ray w on, looking up at the table. He shines his flashlight up it illuminates -- A RED RIBBON, tied on stakes on a ridge. Ten stakes. Twen stakes. Ribbons blowing in the wind.
What's that?
Ain't prayer flags, that's for sure.

Ray sweeps the light along, walking faster, and then some frightening occurs. Something... some unseen thing snags by the leg, sucking him into the Earth with a horrible GU SOUND. Ray is drawn into a hole up to his hips, a bluish-black s oozing out around him. Crow Horse grabs him, struggling t pull him up. He does, stumbling back and stepping into a  hole himself. The two men are wheeling, throwing flashlight beams aroun slapping through a wet jelly, and finally getting their  bearings. Ray touches the ground where a blue-black chemical soluti oozes out with water from the aquifer below. His flashlig scans -- TWENTY DRILLED HOLES IN THE EARTH. A uranium strip-mining grid laid out in a 50 x 60 pattern. The far side is fence by flagged stakes.
Jesus. Oil?
Uranium. Test holes. Somebody came  in from the Nebraska side, and did  some shotgun testin'. They're gettin'  ready to suck this baby dry.
What?
That's what we're doing here. National  interest. National security. Only  this time it's not gold. It's uranium.
We're standin' on broken treaty  ground, Ray. This ain't supposed to  be here. It'll poison the water.
Leo knew about it. Tried to tell  Jimmy, get the Warriors involved.
So they took care of Leo.
Listen to the water... the river  keeps goin' down then rising again.
Ray goes to another hole and sticks his arm in up to the  elbow, sniffs the solution.
They're drainin' our water table.  That's our life, man...

Ray is looking past Crow Horse at -- Something strange in the moonlight. COYOTES. Some forty y away, on a flat stretch of stoney ground. Six Coyotes, da in the shadows of rock formations. MOVING IN ON THEM as R walks forward, they circle... scatter... run back... circ again. Look straight at Ray, eyes glowing. And run.
and Crow Horse walk toward them. To the place they just l A place in the dirt, they were digging up. When they reac it, they stare down into the dirt.

lies there, face down. Denim jacket and a shock of black  hair, thrown into tangles and dirt. It was buried. Until coyote caught wind. Crow Horse bends down, touches the  jacket... turns the body over And almost vomits when he s Maggie Eagle Bear.
looks down in disbelief.
No. No...
Ray steps back, his boots squishing in solution and seala and soiled water. He covers his mouth, stopping himself f getting sick. And then he explodes, YELLING.
in the moonlight. And RAY'S YELLING ECHOING up out of the rocks

The sordid little village the feds first drove through si sleepy on the rim of sunrise. A DOG BARKS hollow as the Crow Horse motorcycle chutters  down and coasts up in front of one of the little homes -- rundown but it has a satellite dish and a decent car like many. The Le Baron pulls up behind it.
Crow Horse walks over to Ray's window, his jeans and boot muddy. No one speaks for a long moment, the night filled crickets. And that one dog.
This Clear Moon's house?
Yeah. It's time to beat the drum.  You better wait here. He don't trust  the white man.

Crow Horse crosses the street. Ray sits there, and he loo almost hurt by this statement. But he is the white man. B he is Indian. He lets a long breath escape, rubs at a tem He takes out a smoke. Tries to light it. His hands are sh too badly. But he gets it lit, and sits tense, looking in his rearview.

Oliver Clear Moon sits in a chair, his strong Indian mout beginning to tighten at the jowls. Across from him, Crow Horse sits on the edge of a couch.  MRS. CLEAR MOON, a rotund, gentle woman brings him a coff A TEENAGE GIRL in a men's extra-large T-shirt stands in t hall, looking at him. Clear Moon in pajamas, rises, and with a coffee in hand,  starts walking in slow steps toward the kitchen. He loses control before he gets there and hurls the cup across the room into the sink, smashing it. He wheels and faces Crow Horse. He SPEAKS LAKOTA. Asking questions. Crow Horse SPE LAKOTA. Answering him. Mrs. Clear Moon, understanding, shakes her head in disbel and her eyes begin to well. Oliver, walking back to his c sits, and thinks for a moment. MORE LAKOTA. He gets up, g to a drawer and rummages. He sits again, and tosses somet onto the coffee table. It is a badge. A tribal police bad
Ray nervously awaits Crow Horse's words as he appears at window again. The Indian shows hope in his tired eyes.

Alright. Shit's comin' down. He's  callin' council fire. All the old  chiefs and the warriors, too. I gotta  be at Grandpa's place in two hours.  We need to get the tribe together.  We need to block this thing.
What we need... is Richard Yellow  Bird.
Crow Horse looks at Ray who stares dead ahead.
The shack is just as Ray left it earlier, kerosene flicke dancing yellow through the gapped boards. Ray and Crow Ho with guns drawn, approach the front door.
I thought it was a rare case of a  brother getting a break in the courts.  We did an honorin' song for him and  everything.
He's looking at a few hundred years  in Leavenworth. He's not gonna come  out without a fight.
Crow Horse snakes around toward the rear of the shack. Ray knocks at the front door. It is unlatched and it crea open a little. Ray pushes it open and sees --
An empty wheelchair.

Ray steps away from the door, looking around the vast pla as the sun comes up out of the Black Hills. He is roadblo and it shows in his eyes. It's all getting too big. Crow Horse leans against the shack, watching Ray. And the RADIO STATIC from inside the Le Baron. Ray pivots and sta at it as if someone is inside the car. His call signal is being paged. But he just stands there, looking at it.
X21. Read. X21...
Ray reaches inside the car and lifts the handset. He take breath before pressing it to his lips.
X21. Come back.
Ray. What's your 20?
Ray looks at Crow Horse who looks equally spooked. The ag clears his throat.
Reservation.
A long, unnerving pause. No response from the other side.
What are you doing on the reservation?
I'm on my way back in. Over.
Ray holds the handset down at his side, looking over the of the car toward the Black Hills.
Ray. Ray, don't let go now, Man.  Ray...
You go to the council fire. I'm going  back in.
Ray.
Ray swings in behind the wheel, starts the car, and barre off recklessly down the rutted road, leaving Crow Horse  behind.
Ray!
The Le Baron is already out to where sight reaches farthe than sound and silent white dust mushrooms skyward.

A RAVEN is sentinel on a telephone wire that crosses the  road from the bar to motel. A few trucks remain parked in front of the joint. Ray approaches room 13, looking shell-shocked. His boots  leave blue mud prints all the way to the door. He unlocks it.

Ray has cast off his field clothes and is halfway into on of his cleaner suits. He looks haggard but still buoyant, his eyes piercing. The connecting door creaks open and Co walks in. The SAC is freshly showered and he is fidgeting with a Windsor knot. He studies his number two man, says  nothing for a moment but is obviously holding something d His face is a red hue.
(extra casual) Couldn't sleep, Ray?
Ray looks at Cooch. When he speaks, his voice is dry.
No...
Cooch crosses the room, and picks up Ray's jeans which lo like they went through a sandlot tackle match in a mud ho Ray tucks his clean shirt in; watching Cooch.
I had to finish something with Crow  Horse.
Cooch walks up to Ray slowly and takes his face in his ha turning it toward lamp light to study the bruise along hi left eye, a residual from a Crow Horse hook.
That's where you were. You had to go  back and have it out with the Indian  law...
Ray nods, and Cooch slowly breaks a smile. An insecure sm but a smile just the same. He starts to laugh.
You fucking hot head, we can get in  trouble for that.

Cooch laughs in amusement and Ray's face crinkles into a  grin as he lowers his eyes, wiping a paper towel over his face. And then, suddenly, Ray lunges at Cooch. He slams the Agent in Charge against the hollow wall, and holds him there. His eyes wild.
Why didn't you tell me what we were  doing here?
Cooch is stunned.
We're running a cover-up and you  didn't --
Cooch suddenly explodes, throwing Ray off of him and send him reeling back against the sink. He points a finger at charge.
You ever put your hands on me again  and you'll be doing the books for a  baitshop in the fucking Everglades,  Mister.
You didn't tell me about Red Deer  Table --
-- what the hell is Red Deer Table?
What is it? It's genocide, that's  what it is. It's a Pay Zone for some  U.S. corporation and a Dead Zone for  the people here. Uranium, Cooch.
Cooch's eyes go frighteningly cold. He can't believe what he's hearing.
Jesus Christ. What are you doing?  What the hell were you doing out  there?
Ray says nothing. He just stands there, against the sink, breathing like a fighter against the turnbuckle.

This was a Selective Operations Unit,  Agent Levoi. There is classified  information pertaining to our national  security. You don't question that,  you don't go digging into that shit --  that's insubordination. Jesus Christ --
-- if they mine uranium there, these  people will have no place left to  go...
We were sworn in on the Constitution  to protect federal matters, Ray. I  don't know about uranium, I don't  know about Red Dog Table -- all I  know is we did our job. It's over.
We neutralized anybody with a voice.  Leo, Jimmy... Eagle Bear. Anyone who  was standing in the way of the land.  Is that it?
No. We neutralized enemies of the  United States. Anti-American radicals  who have killed federal officers out  here!
Ray turns to the sink, turns the faucet on to get some wa on his face. The water only trickles into the basin.

Jesus, Ray. You think I don't like  the Indians? Not true. These were  noble people but their day is gone.  They're a conquered nation. They  want all of America back but they  can't even keep the garbage out of  their own front yards. It's sad,  Ray. But it's just the way it is. We  have to function as a colonial police  force out here.

Ray leans on the sink, watching the water start to spurt  free. He shuts it off. Turns to look at Cooch. And it is  then the door opens -- some knocking after the door is al opened -- and SA Miles enters.
You gentlemen ready -- hi, Ray.
Yeah, we're ready.
Ray doesn't turn from the sink.
Crow Horse chugs along on his motorbike toward the counci his long hair and eagle feather trailing in the wind.

Two federal vehicles are waiting in front of Cooch's Chev and Ray's Le Baron. One is an FBI van where Sherman helps THREE AGENTS load file boxes and computers. Cooch walks with Ray toward the Le Baron, looking at him the go. Ray looks better as he breathes the morning air. they pass the second fed car, the back window power glide down, and someone looks out with a friendly smile.
Ah, there you are. The Sioux.
Ray stops dead. Beholds the Tribal President who wears a  western cut jacket and a strained expression behind his s He hole a hand out to Ray.
You got the troublemakers off our  land. Good, Was-te.

Ray stares at him, speechless. Horrified. What is he doin here? What about the council fire? Ray somehow nods. Then walks on to the Le Baron. Cooch gets behind the wheel of car that Clear Moon sits in. Clear Moon's eyes follow Ray the car.

Crow Horse guns past a little shack. As he does, he looks his side mirror then out across the grasslands. Then quic IN HIS MIRROR: a car has pulled out from behind the shack CROW HORSE observes this. Then twists the fuel throttle h

Ray gets behind the wheel, looks at his watch. He is  panicking. He starts the car, reverses, slams into drive. RAYS POV: swerving and reckless as he races forward. Sher walking around to one of the cars has to run out of the w The other agents clear out, looking in confusion as Ray c a hard U -- sweeps PAST THE BAR, SMASHES INTO AND THROUGH the old hitching post -- and HEADS TOWARD the reservation which lies vast before him.
With agents scrambling about, looking after the car, Cooc gets out, looking into the dust Ray left behind. HEARTBEA DRUM.
RAY!

Sherman appears beside Cooch aiming a questioning look. W Cooch quickly gets back behind the wheel, Sherman pulls h radio up and starts yelling into it. Cooch reaches out the window and grabs his radio arm.
No, damn it. You call teams in and  this is gonna be a fucking media  event. Get me three cars, six agents,  block all reservation exits. It's  under control.
And Cooch squeals out with a petrified Clear Moon in the  backseat, inquiring nervously.

Crow Horse passes by an abandoned horse trailer. When he  does, another car pulls out. And follows. The first car p by. Crow Horse sees he's being followed. He cranks his thrott and the engine grinds then dies. He heels his kickstart o the fly, and keeps it alive. But his old horse is no matc for the big engines coming up fast behind him.
Ray is leaving little transitional developments and trail behind. His eyes bore into the road before him, looking f a sign of Crow Horse, and in the rearview for a sign of h FBI mentor.

Crow Horse has the throttle open. But the two cars are co up on both sides, trying to sandwich him. To his right th Badlands loom deep, a drop into a caliche netherworld of  jagged rock. He throws the bike right, trying to ride the thin ribbon shoulder.
floors it, and swipes him, and the bike goes over the edg launched into --
where it does a violent triple flip, throwing Crow Horse  then smashing into a tent shaped dune.
sticks out from a window and punches the Badlands with TH SHOTS.

The Le Baron rifles past the abandoned horse trailer. Bla smoke drifts in a wind ahead. Ray veers onto the shoulder, barely gets the car in park  before bailing and running wildly down into the Badlands.
Ray runs, stumbles through the rock and gypsum, searching the area. He runs around the burning motorcycle, looking  left and right.
Crow Horse!
lies on his back in the Badlands, eyes open, fixed unmovi on the sky. Ray comes out of the flame-waves, running wit his .45 held high. He throws himself to his knees beside injured Indian.
Crow Horse!
Crow Horse rolls his eyes toward the FBI agent. He has a  gash behind his ear, and pink sand clings to the blood. H lifts his head, tries to form words.
Ain't no Council Fire, Brother. Clear  Moon...
I know. Come on. We gotta get off  the reservation or we're dead.
Hoka Hey. It's a good day to die.
Bullshit, let's get outta here,
Ray gets an arm under the big Indian, helps him up out of jagged crevice.
Grandpa...
Cooch's car speeds down the stretch. Followed by Sherman' The FBI van. All at one-hundred and five. Gravel and dirt flies.
With Crow Horse half-passed out in the passenger seat, Ra keeps the wheel steady. And then his RADIO STATICS.
X21, please read. Ray. Ray. X21,  please read. This is Cooch. Please  come in, Ray. Where are you?
Ray just stares down at the radio, keeps the pedal floore The throws the wheel left.

The Le Baron fish-tails in a cloud of dust and Ray leaps of the car, runs toward the little trailer, gun in hand. windows are all busted, and the door is wide open. Ray ru in. Then straight back out, shaking his head to Crow Hors Crow Horse hangs his head out the passenger window.
He's gone.
He hasn't left this place in twenty  years. They got him.
Ray starts to get back in then hesitates. He looks out ac the plains to see -- THREE FED CARS in the distance, fast approaching, dust ri Ray gets in quickly.
Cooch's car is parked in a roadblock. Clear Moon stands n him, and addresses UNIFORMED TRIBAL POLICE as they spill from a van, carrying rifles and shotguns.
(into radio) X21. Ray. Ray, please come in.
Cooch has torn his tie away, his shirt is open, and he is sweat soaked. Miles gets out of a car that pulls up.
We have a renegade agent, Cooch? He  gets off the reservation...
-- he's not getting off the  reservation.
And Cooch gets back in the car, drives off.
With Ray driving like a maniac, Crow Horse is turned arou in his seat, watching the federal cars spreading out, the chopper moving in.
They got us sealed. What are we gonna  do?
We're going for The Stronghold.
Crow Horse looks at him.

(Cooch) Ray. Can you hear me? You are fucked.  There's no way out of this. If you  won't listen to your own laws, then  listen to this: (static: a new voice) This is President Clear Moon. This  nation does not want your sympathy.  You cannot use this reservation as a  sanctuary. Stop where you are now.
Ray and Crow Horse exchange a look.
(Cooch) Whatever you are trying to do is  futile, Raymond. You have nothing.  Nothing.
Ray picks up the mic as he cranes to keep an eye on the  rearview.
Yellow bird... is gonna sing.
(Cooch) Yellow Bird committed suicide at  three o'clock this morning. Some  gung-ho agent from D.C. pushed him  into a corner. You're playing a losing  game. Pull over.

Ray takes the mic and for some reason, he's putting it in his jacket near his shoulder where he keeps his leather.  Crow Horse looks at him, puzzled. And then the sound come forth, the static crackling of a micro-cassette recorder.
(Ray) How the hell do you know? (Yellow Bird) I blew his back out with a buffalo  gun, that's how I know. And now you're  gonna say I didn't and put me back  in solitary?!
Ray keeps the tape running into the radio as he drives th rugged Badlands. Crow Horse, stunned by the voice, eyes R as the tape rolls.
Cooch and Clear Moon stare in horror at the radio.
(Yellow Bird) You people tol' me I could beat nine  years if I helped you. I helped you! (rewinding) I could beat nine years if I helped  you. I helped you!
Cooch is shaking his head in vitrified disbelief. He slam the pedal almost through the floor.
The tape ends and Ray now lifts the mic to his mouth.
(into mic) Fuck you.
And he too, buries the accelerator.
The Le Baron burns forward and we SWEEP UP TO A MIND-BLOW AERIAL VIEW of the Badlands as four fed cars spread out i formation, following.
Crow Horse is turned around, looking at the pursuit.
Walter.
Crow Horse turns, sees what Ray is looking at. POV: The Stronghold -- a narrow opening in hulking rock  formations. Large enough for a car to get in, and keep  followers out.
That's it. The Stronghold. Get us in  there, we got a chance.
We're in there. We're in there --
just ahead, the earth is gone. A wavering heat pond turns out to be a crevice and they nose down into it, burying t front end in sand and rock. WINDSHIELD SHATTERS.
The Le Baron is stuck, wheels spinning out. Ray and Cooch bail. Guns drawn, they start running for the Stronghold.

head_text.subj: AT THE EDGE OF THE ARROYO

text: the caravan slides in recklessly, two of the fed cars com dangerously close to going over the edge. The regional  officers and six Clear Moon goons empty out, running down the dip, rifles and shotguns ready. Three more field agents come down from another direction, followed by Cooch. Sherman hands a bullhorn to him.
(via bullhorn) FREEZE! NOW!
The sound of FIFTEEN PRIMING FIREARMS stops Ray and Crow  Horse in their tracks. Just twenty feet from The Strongho Crow Horse, windless, stumbles to a knee. Ray turns slowl facing the small army.
DROP IT.
Crow Horse, rises, sucking wind, and ditches his gun in t Badlands. Ray holds onto his .45 a moment longer. Then dr it. He stares at --

Cooch, SA Miles, SA Sherman, Six regional officers, six C Moon goons. And now, coming out of the backseat of Cooch' Chevy, Oliver Clear Moon, walking tentatively, cautiously Cooch lowers the bullhorn. He takes the opportunity to st at Ray. To let Ray stare at him. The older agent looks br
Crow Horse, get your face in the  dirt. Ray... come forward. Let it  go. Let's just let it go...
Crow Horse lowers himself to a knee then lies face down. just stands there, the wind against him.
Come on, Ray. Come forward.
No way, Cooch.
Ray refuses to move.
sweating, tries to keep control. All around him, hands ar on guns. Cooch is walking toward Ray.
Ray. I'm coming to talk to you. I'm  gonna walk you out of here. And we're  gonna get the hell outta this place.

Cooch walks toward him, a gun hanging at one side, bullho at the other. The agents behind him, around him, all rais rifles, all take aim. Sherman, looking sick, gets to a knee and sets aim. The s of clacking steel, all around. But Cooch seems disturbed the sound. Because its coming from above. He raises an ey from the rifle sight to see --

head_text.subj: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE

text: FIFTEEN INDIANS, training rifles and shotguns down below.
looks up from his rifle, bewildered. Then alarmed.

head_text.subj: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE

text: We PAN across fifteen Indians -- old people, women, kids. Their weapons are weak but many. And at the end of the row, Maisy Blue Legs rises, clutchi a rifle. And PAST HER, ANOTHER. TRADITIONAL PEOPLE, many  from the trading post porch, rise to the edge, armed. Sil Twenty, twenty-five, thirty traditionals, forming a line  along the ridge, a line that runs in a circle, broken by Stronghold entrance, then starting again on the next butt Thirty-five, forty of them. And more, standing along the  opposite craggy rock, some wearing tractor caps, some cow hats, some just long hair blowing in the wind. Fifty, six SEVENTY-FIVE RESERVATION PEOPLE forming a circle on the r it's Little Big Horn revisited. A fourteen year-old boy  struggles to keep a huge shotgun at his shoulder.
Clear Moon's mouth is as dry as Badlands soil. Cooch is  panicking, his eyes running along the high edge.
stands equally astonished, assessing the back-up.
lifts himself, stands, taking in the sight.

head_text.subj: AT THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE

text: stepping stiffly but steadily through the line of armed  locals, pushing his way to the very edge so as to look do Grandpa Sam Reaches. The wind makes feathery tails out of his long thinning strips of white hair.
Ray looks up at the old man, then turns to face Cooch.
You're right, Cooch. It's over.

Cooch slowly, lets the bullhorn fall. Then the rifle. He  looks back at Sherman who does the same, and all the way  down the line, everyone dropping their arms under the thr of a lot more guns from above. And now Ray walks forward, collecting his gun. Anderson Chasing Hawk, one of the  Warriors, runs down to Ray, breathless.
All the exits are blocked. There's  two more fed cars tryin' to get in.  And some press.
Ray notices that Cooch is staring at him, hard. He shakes his head slowly. Strongly.
Ray...
Let the press through.
Chasing Hawk takes off, running, and Cooch watches in  consternation. Ray just stands eye to eye with him, holdi his ground.

And along the ridge, Grandpa and the locals don't budge,  watching every move. CLIMBING HIGHER, we rise above the circle of proud Sioux see, on the inside of the Stronghold, thirty old trucks a res cars. CLIMBING HIGHER into and through the fast-moving clouds t the Lakota call The Grandfathers as the HEARTBEAT DRUM an LAKOTA SINGERS takes over all sound.

The HIGH WINDS of THREE MEDIA HELICOPTERS are delighting storm of Indian children and BARKING DOGS, running throug the streets past junked cars on blocks. Over on a little plot of grass and dirt, a pair of hands digging a small hole. Ray lays a pine cone in the hole an looks down at it for a moment... before hand-plowing the  dirt back over it and patting it flat. He rises, knocking dirt off his knees and hands. Crow Horse walks over, bandaged and favoring wounds, and falls in with him, walking down the middle of the village road. His eyes are tired. But hopeful.
The people are already talkin' about  their vote for a new tribal prez.  They wanna vote for Jimmy.
Ray nods, encouraged as they walk along. His eyes follow helicopters.
What about the water...
You bought her some time, Kola. Ain't  never gonna be over... but you bought  her some time.
Some Indian time?
They reach the dusty, dented Le Baron and stand there, lo at each other.
Indian time.
Crow Horse offers a hand to Ray. He takes it in a white m shake then follows Walter's cue into the Indian "allies"  grip and slap. They hold it there, looking into each othe eyes.
(concerned) Where ya gonna go, Ray?
Ray ponders for a moment.
I'll have to see what the visions  say about that one.
You didn't have another vision...
Ray shrugs. Crow Horse discreetly gestures below his belt
Yeah, right here.
Ray cracks a smile, a long time coming.
You take care.
If you ever need a place to come  back to and listen to the trees a  little... we'll be here.
Ray stands looking at him, searching for words.
Ain't no word in Sioux for goodbye.

Ray goes to get in his car. But he sees someone sitting a the street on the trading post porch. The old man. Ray considers him for a moment then walks over. They lock eyes. Grandpa stares at Ray as if he's never seen him bef and then arcs a brow. He touches his sleeve at the wrist. Ray rolls his sleeve back to reveal his Rolex. Grandpa sm and Ray strips it off. He hands it to the old man and his face crinkles into caliche earth. Grandpa holds the watch up in the light, admires it then  puts it in his shirt pocket. He moves a flat hand through the air in the "done deal" sign language. Ray, a little  surprised that he gets nothing in the trade, returns the  smile and walks away. He gets to his car and wipes away two inches of dust from the broken windshield.

After THREE TRIES, he gets the engine started. He pulls h gun off his waistband, goes to lay it on the passenger se and finds something there. Grandpa's sacred caanunpa. The Pipe. Symbol of truth. Ray looks out the window at the old man who is watching him w those sharp black eyes. Ray lifts his hand, holds it flat and does the Sioux done deal sign.

The Le Baron eats up the dirt road at a moderate, gravel  crunching pace. It slows as it passes Maggie Eagle Bear's quiet home on the river. Children walk with the old woman carrying buckets from the river. The Le Baron slows to a crawl, then drives on.
where the elders sit, watching the dust blow.
(voice lingering) We will be here.
CROW HORSE walking off down the road. He stops, and looks over his shoulder, trying to glimpse the distance.

THE LE BARON driving off the res, under big sky as it asc a rough hill, waddles through potholes, negotiates with s horses in the road and rolls on toward the reservation li where the sun throws shadows that look like an old man  dancing.

head_text.subj: AT THE PLACE IN THE ROAD

text: where West goes to Rapid City, and East back to Bear Cree Ray stops like the bullet-punched sign orders. He doesn't West. Doesn't go East. He sits there. Fishes a smoke out  from a pocket, clicks a lighter, and fires up. He sits th smoking. Deliberating. SUDDEN CUT TO BLACK. And after a long silent beat, A DRUM. Like a heart. END CREDITS.
